keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

lead_paragraph: Not communicating to banks exactly what they need to do to get their bankruptcy plans to pass muster is frustrating, confusing and part of the plan.

headline.print_headline: Messing With Minds of Bankers Is Good
headline.main: How Regulators Mess With Bankers’ Minds, and Why That’s Good

snippet: Not communicating to banks exactly what they need to do to get their bankruptcy plans to pass muster is frustrating, confusing and part of the plan.
abstract: The Upshot; Dodd-Frank Act has built-in safeguards allowing federal regulators to update provisions as financial system itself changes; example is seen in decision not to disseminate changes to requirements for filing special plans, or living wills, documents proving big banks have detailed plans in place for orderly bankruptcy; idea behind not communicating exactly what information needs to be included plans is to keep them from becoming mere compliance exercise.
